content.description:
Farthest left route on the wall. 
Climb up to a small roof and into an awkward corner. Finish at the shared anchor. 

Far left side of the wall, under a small roof.
Gear to 2"

Start in the corner and go up to a roof. Work up through a slot to a layback.
Can finish to the left on the shared anchor, or continue upwards to the tree.

Left side of the main wall, starting in a wide corner. 
Gear to 3"

A very wild, varied journey on excellent rock. One of the best 5.7s in Squamish, not often you get to climb so many unique styles in a single route.

Start on steep jugs, clipping a bolt and plugging extra gear if you wish. Next, move onto the low-angle face for a few delicate thin and balancy moves as you climb left through glacier polish into a friendly (but steep) layback flake. Layback or jam up the flake, then foot-traverse along the top of it left for 10 feet (unprotectable but easy, place a #2 or #3 Camalot at the top of the flake before the traverse) until you get to a beautiful hand-crack. Get to jamming, the crack goes from #3 to #1 Camalots if I remember correctly. At the giant perched boulder, traverse left underneath it, then walk up a bit to a steep, blocky chimney finish.

**Be careful when lowering. This is a rope-stretcher even with a 70m, tie knots in your rope** Another option is to bring up your second and walk off together, potentially safer.

Because of the nature of the flake it's almost invisible until you traverse up the trail far enough, then it will seem obvious. It takes the line to the left of the low-angle slab route directly up the face with a line of bolts. 
Standard rack to #3. You can find a place for a #4. I'd take doubles from 0.75 to #2. There are also two bolts you can clip at the start. Bolted anchor at the top.

climbs.name: Peanuts
climbs.fa: C. Austrom, 1978. FFA: B. Milward, J. Campbell, 1983

content.description:
Challenging route up a groove.
Walk off the top towards the left. 

Left side of the wall, to the left of an open project with two bolts on it. 
Gear to 3"

Go up the obvious dirty crack, tending slightly left to the shared anchor. 

Crack on the far left side of the wall.
Gear to 3"

Strenuous and bouldery climb up the centre of the wall. 

In the middle of the main wall, starting just to the right of the left facing corner. 
Gear, #0 - #2 + 3 Bolts

Shares a start with Garfield, but then step right onto the slab. Follow the slab up to a dirty crack. 

Shares start with Garfield, but then goes straight up the slab.
Gear to 2" + 5 Bolts
A tall, south/east facing crag with a variety of different styles - mostly old school.
